Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my parents, just like I promised. It’s our tradition—me sitting on my bed, phone pressed to my ear, listening to Mom’s gentle questions and Dad’s quiet laughter. They expect me to share everything: my classes, my friends, even the little things that bother me. Tonight, though, my heart pounds as I dial. This week, I saw a friend cheat on an exam. I know, as a Christian, I should be honest and maybe even encourage my friend to come clean. But if I tell my parents, they’ll worry, maybe even call the school. If I don’t, I feel like I’m hiding the truth, betraying my values. My parents want to know everything, to trust me. My faith tells me to act with integrity. I stare at the ceiling, phone ringing, torn between being the open, honest child they expect and the Christian who must stand for what’s right, even if it means causing trouble. The line clicks, and I hear my mom’s voice, warm and expectant. My throat tightens as I try to decide what to say.
